repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

did.unittitle: Michael Ratner Papers

physdesc.extent: in 108 record cartons, 3 manuscript boxes, 1 half manuscript box, 1 oversize flat box, and 1 card box
in 57 word processing files on 2 floppy disks (3.5 inch), and 2 floppy disks (5.25 inch)
on 5 DVDs, 11 audio CDs, and 6 CD-Rs

did.abstract: This collection contains the personal and professional papers of Michael Ratner. Ratner is a human rights attorney who served for many years as the President of the Center for Constitutional Rights. The first donation of his papers in 2009 consist of 74 boxes containing legal files, correspondence, articles, research, notes, born-digital, and audiovisual materials. These materials relate to Ratner's work with the Center for Constitutional Rights (CCR) and his work more generally in human rights law and human rights activism. An additional 9 boxes received in Spring 2016 contain Ratner's correspondence and research files between 1993 and 2015. An additional 5 boxes received in Fall 2016 contain notes and drafts related to Ratner's publications and research between 1970 and 2014. An additional 4 boxes received in 2017 contain Ratner's notes, articles, case summaries, and correspondence related to legal cases between 1995 and 2006. An accretion added to the collection in fall 2017 contains research file and clippings on the United States War on Terror and War in Iraq.
did.physloc: Materials in this collection are stored offsite and advance notice is required for their use. Please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu at least two business days prior to visiting the library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Repository permission is required for access. Please contact Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor, tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu, 212-998-2630.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Placed on temporary loan in 2009 and dontaed in 2011 by Michael Ratner; addtional materials were donated by Karen Ranucci in 2016, 2017, and 2019. The accession numbers associated with these gifts are 2009.082, 2016.013, 2016.043, 2017.005, 2017.047, and 2019.073.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Michael Ratner is an attorney whose work has focused on human rights abuses in the United States and abroad. He was born in Ohio in 1943. He received a BA from Brandeis University and his law degree from Columbia University, and has credited his time at Brandeis for encouraging his political activism. Ratner worked for many years at the Center for Constitutional Rights (CCR), a non-profit human rights litigation organization. Through the CCR, Ratner worked on first federal lawsuit in the Attica Brothers vs. Rockefeller, which took up the case of Attica prison inmates. He later served as principal council in a suit to close a detention camp for HIV-positive Haitian refugees at the United States' military base in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. Throughout Ratner's long career with the CCR he has served in a number of leadership positions including legal director, vice-president, and eventually president. He has also worked as a lecturer at Yale and a professor at Columbia Law School and has served as legal advisor to notable individuals including Julian Assange of Wikileaks.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Michael Ratner Papers; TAM 518; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library & Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was received in multiple donations. The first donation received in 2009 consists of 74 boxes and was rehoused into archival boxes. Two of these boxes (Box 95 and Box 96) contain mold and have been placed in the Quarantine Room. There are an additional 6 boxes among these materials for which there is no acquisition information. It is unclear whether these boxes came as part of the original donation or a later accretion.

14 additional boxes were added to the collection in 2 accretions in 2016. Materials from these donations were added as the following subseries: Spring 2016 Accretion and Fall 2016 Accretion in a new series titled: Accretions. In 2017 an accretion of 4 boxes was added as the subseries 2017 Accretion. Materials have been rehoused into archival boxes, and retained in their original groupings. Any items that were loose in the boxes have been placed in archival folders, but no attempt has been made to rearrange folders or materials within the boxes.
Disk images of born-digital items in 2016 and 2017 accretions were made at the time of accessioning.

In July 2017 a box level inventory was created for the collection, including the original donation (2009) and the accretions (2016 and 2017). Loose materials found in the boxes have been placed in archival folders, but no attempt has been made to rearrange folders or materials within the boxes. Born-digital and audiovisual materials have been separated from their original boxes and consolidated into two boxes (Box 73 and Box 90). A separation sheet was placed in the original box and folder of the born-digital/AV item(s), and a second separation sheet was placed with the born-digital/AV item(s) in the new box. These materials are also described in the inventory.

In September 2017, 11 boxes were added to the collection as the subseries September 2017 Accretion. At the time of acccessioning these materials were described at the series level and listed in a box-level inventory. Items in this accretion have not been arranged by an archivist. CD-Rs and DVD-Rs containing audio recordings were moved to box 90 and separation sheets were placed in their original locations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the personal and professional papers of human rights attorney Michael Ratner. The 2009 donation consists of 74 boxes. These materials relate to Ratner's work with the Center for Constitutional Rights (CCR) and his work more generally in human rights law and human rights activism. Materials include notes, articles, case summaries, research, correspondence, audiovisual material, and born-digital material related to legal cases on a wide array of international human rights topics. Materials also include files containing correspondence, drafts, articles, and research related to conferences, public forums, and publications. Some documents contained within these boxes may be protected by attorney-client privilege.

9 boxes of Ratner's papers were added to this collection in 2016. Before sending these materials to Tamiment, Ratner removed any documents protected by attorney-client privilege. These documents primarily consist of Ratner's research files between 1993 and 2015, which include newspaper clippings, journal articles, legal briefs, and documents on international law. Ratner's research files focus on a handful of specific topics including the detention of HIV-positive Haitian refugees in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, violations of habeas corpus following the September 11th terrorist attacks, the Patriot Act, the United States War on Terror, and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. They also contain a small assortment of emails between Ratner, attorneys, and other human rights activists. There are several drafts of articles for scholarly publication as well as a variety of legal briefs, memoranda, motions, and court orders. Many of these materials relate to Ratner's work with the Center for Constitutional Rights.

5 boxes added to the collection in the fall of 2016 consist of notes and drafts related to Ratner's publications and research. Included among these materials are handwritten and typed notes, outlines, research, and drafts of books and articles on US intervention in Latin America and the Caribbean. They also include research files on former CIA agent Philip Agee from the 1970s and 1980s. There is also an assortment of his correspondence and writing on human rights issues between 2010 and 2014.

An additional 4 boxes added to the collection in 2017 include Ratner's notes, articles, case summaries and correspondence related to legal cases between 1995 and 2006 on a wide array of international human rights topics including, terrorist actions against the Cuban government, United States immigration policy, the United States' War on Terrorism, the arrest of Augosto Pinochet, and the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia. It also includes files containing correspondence, speech drafts, and articles related conferences and public forums on human rights law between 2005 and 2009.

There are an additional 6 boxes in the collection, which arrived prior to the 2016 donation. It is unclear whether these boxes were part of the original donation or a previous accretion. No acquisition information exists for these boxes.

An additional 11 boxes added to the collection in 2017 include clippings and research materails related to the United States War on Terror. They largely consist of newspaper clippings, legal articles, copies of international law, notes, drafts of articles, and correspondence. This donation also includes a small amount of material documenting Ratners work on the radio program Law and Disorder and collected articles written about Ratner by others.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Advance notice is required for the use of computer records. Original physical digital media is restricted. Born-digital materials have not been transferred and may not be available to researchers. Researchers may request access copies. To request that material be transferred, or if you are unsure if material has been transferred, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection, created by Michael Ratner, was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consist of notes and drafts related to Michael Ratner's publications and research donated in Fall 2016. It contains handwritten and typed notes, outlines, research, and drafts for his books "Che Guevara and the FBI: U.S. Political Police Dossier on the Latin American Revolutionary" (1997), "The Pinochet Papers: The Case of Augusto Pinochet in Spain and Britain" (2000), and various books and articles on Guantanamo Bay. These materials also contain research files on former CIA agent Philip Agee, including copies of congressional hearings and briefs, State Department documents regarding Agee's passport denial, and newspaper clippings from the 1970s and 1980s. Other materials in this subseries include assorted correspondence and writing on human rights issues between 2010 and 2014.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accretion includes Michael Ratner's notes, articles, case summaries, and correspondence related to legal cases between 1995 and 2006. They touch on a wide array of topics related to international human rights including, terrorist actions against the Cuban government, United States immigration policy, the United States's War on Terrorism, the arrest of Augosto Pinochet, and the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia. It also includes files containing correspondence, speech drafts, and articles related conferences and public forums related to human rights law between 2005 and 2009.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accretion to the Michael Ratner Papers includes clippings, articles, notes and research materials collected and created by attorney Michael Ratner. Newspaper clippings are grouped by topic and document issues including the US War on Terror, the War in Iraq, Al Qaeda, Sadaam Hussein, George W. Bush, and the Abu Graib prison scandal. Other materials include legal research such as briefs, copies in international laws, scholarly articles, notes, and drafts of papers.The bulk of these research files relate to the United States War on Terror, other research relate to Ratner's work on Che Guevara and the Cuban Five. Writings by Ratner include copies of his articles, dated 2001-2016. The accretion also contains files from Ratner's speaking engagements and materials collected in preparation for legal classes he taught at Yale. There are also a small amount of material related to Ratner's involvement with the radio program Law and Disorder, and articles written about Ratner by others.
